awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Propagation of Dissipation: Stochastic Stabilization in Finite and Infinite Dimensions
awd_abstract_narration:
Randomness is everywhere in modern science and technology. It underlies models of air turbulence, chemical dynamics, and algorithms for big data. Such models are often high dimensional or even infinite dimensional, as in the case of turbulence. Central to understanding these systems is understanding the way both energy and randomness are spread by nonlinear interactions in the dynamics. This research project explores a number of directions that exploit both the geometric and algebraic structures of such systems to better understand these basic transport phenomena. The investigators will work to understand how such interactions can lead to stabilization in systems that are unstable in the absence of randomness. The project includes research participation by graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students.  At the high school level, the investigators will also work to keep the students' teachers connected with cutting-edge mathematics, helping them to be more effective and better informed as teachers. In addition, videos chronicling the student research efforts will be made in collaboration with a center for documentary films to further disseminate the experience and broaden the project's impact. 

This collaborative research project in stochastic analysis and dynamics will explore the propagation of noise and dissipation in stochastic systems and their effects on the existence and structure of stationary states. There is particular emphasis on effects that occur in stochastic partial differential equations, the ability of noise to stabilize unstable systems, and non-equilibrium steady-states in forced systems. Many of the equations to be investigated are physical models (e.g. from fluid mechanics or non-equilibrium statistical physics) while other equations to be studied serve as examples that aid in understanding the underlying mechanisms producing stability or instability in such systems. This work will build on the investigators' previous work in designing Lyapunov functions in the finite-dimensional setting of stochastic ordinary differential equations (SODEs) and establishing practical methods for proving unique ergodicity and convergence to equilibrium in both the finite-dimensional setting of SODEs as well as the infinite-dimensional setting of SPDEs. While the research is anticipated to have immediate implications in fluid mechanics and statistical physics, the techniques that will result from studying such systems will be applicable to a wide family of problems in other areas, such as biology, engineering, physics, and finance, which regularly employ stochastic ordinary and partial differential equations as modeling tools.

por.por_cntn:
The project advanced our understanding of the propagation of randomness and dissipative effects in important nonlinear systems including the motion of fluids and those simple models of molecular interactions. Understanding the interaction of these effects is central to many questions of broad interesest in science and technology. These advances required understanding the delicate interplay between the noise which is injecting energy and activity to a system and the dissipation which is removing energy from the system. The work in this grant helped understand how noise can help stabiles the systems and give rise to interesting long time statistical states. One system studies were networks of chemical reaction as found in living cells. These and related considerations are central to understanding turbulent fluid flow which is one of the great unsolved scientific questions. A related paper showed how in some setting these non-linear interactions did not change the fine scale structure of the flow in some fluid models. This helps us better understand when the nonlinearity is important and when it has little effect. A number of the ideas from these works were used to understand th behavior of high-dimensional algorithms used in machine learning and big-data.

The grant also lead to the first demonstration of the convergence of a class of sampling algorithms, used in computational chemistry and statistics. These algorithms are based breaking the problems up into smaller problem whose solutions are then stitched together into the full solution. These "stratified" sampling schemes are well suited to modern computers which have many computational cores.

The grant also advanced our understanding of the formation of singular structures in a class of stochastic process called Piecewise-Deterministic. This class has gained a lot of popularity recently for there use in modeling biological systems and designing efficient sampling methods.

This grant resulted in 21 new scientific papers which where disseminated to the larger scientific community. All papers were submitted for publication to traditional journals and were simultaneously published freely to open-access science archives to reduce the barriers to the transmission of scientific ideas.
This grant directly supported two PhD students who successful defended theses whose projects which were directly related to the intellectual content of this grant. One is now a postdoctoral fellow at University of Massachusetts-Amherst and the other entered the private sector to work in the finical industry. Two post-doctoral fellows also continued their training on the project supported in this grant. Both now have tenure-track academic jobs teaching mathematics and conducting research; one at University of Massachusetts-Amherst and the other at the University of Pisa, Italy. Two current graduate students are currently working on project which grew out of this grant. In addition two students from neighboring institutions (UNC Chapel Hill and the Georgia Institute of Technology) received part of their graduate training on project which were part of this grant. A post-doctoral fellow at UCLA as also worked on projects in the grant. Lastly two teams of high school students for Durham area high-schools participated in year long or summer research projects with the researchers and postdoctoral fellows in this grant. At least three of these students are now majoring in mathematics in college. A number of undergraduate research project were also conducted by the researchers support by this grant.
